This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14460663
Depends on how you look at it, but I was watching a documentary filmed on the Falkland Islands in 1983 about the post-war situation:

https://youtu.be/24Bx4h01wTM

Interesting thing about it, most of the population were tenant farmers and most of the island was privately owned by a single company and then some absentee landlords who weren't investing in it. One island in the west, Saunders Island, was owned by absentee Argentine landlords who sued the British government for damages caused during the war.

It's basically a leftover from feudalism. Saunders is now not owned by them anymore, it's owned by the family who works that land (sheep herding). And the British government spent a lot of aid funds to help tenant farmers buy land, which was different from straight-up expropriation and redistribution but basically the same idea, and is something the war accelerated. I haven't looked that much into the specifics of how far that went but "large swathes of land owned by absentee landlords:" was "subdivided and sold to Falkland Islands residents."

And that did involve state intervention to finesse that process.

posts.name: Was he a prophet?
posts.com:
So if you follow the implications, justifications for private property can often be to just rationalize the status quo, which in the case of the Falklands, was just a monopolistic landlord owning half the place with most of the rest owned by absentee landlords, in some cases the government didn't even know who they were, they didn't even live on the Falkland Islands, and just owned this land extracted rents from it while not investing in it to make it more productive.

Very simply investments in this case because it's all sheep herding. Which means... fences. And maybe a new building that's bigger to shear more sheep in. (And in the case of post-war Falklands, repairing damages to the land.) So is it "wrong" to take that land and redistribute it to the people who actually work the land? Is that "socialism?"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Marxists believe capitalists "exploit" workers by owning property. Therefore if everyone owned everything then there wouldn't be exploitation. The problems with this view are many but the main flaws are

>workers aren't exploited.
>all goods and resources are scarce with competing uses. Without a market to allocate goods the only alternative is an authoritarian state with a class of bureaucrats deciding who gets what.
>owning capital doesn't magically make wealth appear in your lap while you put your feet on the desk and smoke cigars. It has to be allocated to uses that people value. Nobody ever got rich owning a mud pie factory.
>without property owners having skin in the game, there's no incentive to use capital to provide value and reduce waste. The Soviet Union was notorious for shortages of basic goods while factories rusted away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14461823
>workers aren't exploited ... Without a market to allocate goods
Even from a Marxist perspective, the marketplace is fair though. You buy and sell at a price reflecting cost of production into that price. The capitalist provides goods and reasonable prices according to what they're worth, and the worker exchanges their labor power to the capitalist for what it costs to reproduce it. This is sort of where the liberal analysis ends, though. The liberal analysis just sees the transaction, decides it's fair, and moves on. The billionaire contributes his capital, the worker contributes his labor, commodities are produced, and then exchanged for fair prices. Everything is fair and everyone is happy!

But Where the Marxist criticism comes in is that focusing purely on the marketplace only focuses on a relationship between things bought and sold on the market, but ignores the social relationships between the people themselves. And to find the people, you have to look at the people producing stuff, not just looking at the stuff being bought and sold.

That means looking at Amazon, but instead of the products being bought and sold, you look inside Amazon and see a bunch of miserable people with low wages working in crummy conditions and peeing in bottles because they aren't even given a bathroom break. So basically there's a power imbalance here. But the free-market libertarian will say, well, they chose to work there. But if fair is fair, then they have a right to choose to form a union and collectively bargain for better wages and conditions.

Yes, but not that it matters. The risk of the death penalty rests on the integrity of the justice system and the socius its body of law governs. Prohibition of capital punishment naturally comes into force where people do not trust their or their institutions' discernment. It's a libertarian safeguard put into place where the risk of a corrupt justice system is considered at large to be more likely to threaten social function than individual evils. When the social fabric disintegrates for one reason or another and distrust is no longer leveled against the state but against fellow man the reverse tends to be the case. I don't think passing a moral judgement on the practice of capital punishment ultimately says much when both its prohibition and its necessity have been legitimized and argued for in the name of both transcendental and secular causes irrespective of the argued self-consistency of the various related dogma.

The Catholic/Orthodox theology of images is that man-made images (paintings, statues, etc.) are not worshiped but venerated, and that the honor paid to an image passes to its prototype (that whom it depicts). They believe that the cultic use of images (bowing, kissing, processing, praying) is justified by God becoming man, as Christ's human body is understood as an image in a manner that is analogous to man-made images. I won't be making an argument that these distinctions are false, but examining where their logic leads, particularly in relation to man-made images of Christ. I am not also seeking to demonstrate that man-made images in themselves are wrong. Definitions: "worship" is the degree of honor due only to God; "veneration" is a lesser degree of honor which can be given to creatures and objects.

1. If the honor paid to a man-made image passes to its prototype, then worship paid to a man-made image would pass to its prototype. So if a person worshiped a painting of Jesus as if it were God, this worship would pass to Jesus. Catholic/Orthodox theology would state that it is forbidden to worship a man-made image, a piece of wood or stone, as if it were God; but this is still the logic of this understanding of the relation between image and prototype.

2. Given that worship given to a man-made image of Jesus would pass to Jesus, but this is forbidden, it means that there is a fundamental distinction between man-made images and the image of Christ's human body. No one would claim that if Jesus were standing physically in front of them, that the proper response would not be to worship him as God, despite him being present in an image. But this is denied for man-made images. So man-made images and Christ's body are both "images" only in the broadest sense of the term, and are not actually analogous to each other.

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14456947
3. If worship cannot be paid to a man-made image of God, that is, if one cannot worship a painting or statue as if it were God, this means that God can only be worshiped without images. If one wishes to worship God, they cannot do so by utilizing a man-made image. One could venerate God through a man-made image, but one cannot worship God through a man-made image. God can only be worshiped without man-made images. Frankly, I think this point alone vitiates the fundamental claim of iconoclasts.

4. This begs the question of why I would want to venerate God through a man-made image when the proper response of the soul to God is to worship him. If Christ were physically before me, I would not want to simply venerate him, that is, to give him the honor I would give to merely a man. He is my God, and I would want to worship him as my God. So by utilizing a man-made image of Christ, I am actually unable to pay Christ the honor that he is properly due. Perhaps one could say there is worth in, at times, giving God less honor than what he deserves; this strikes me as impious.

5. A way around this would be to claim that worship of images is actually acceptable. In which case, you are worshiping a rock or a piece of wood as if it is your God. Your intention is indeed that the true God is worshiped, but you are still paying the worship due to the living God to a rock or to a stone. The idea that this would not constitute idolatry is absurd.

(2/2)

Pope Gregory the Great (d. 604), letter to Serenus, Bishop of Massilia:
"Furthermore we notify to you that it has come to our ears that your Fraternity, seeing certain adorers of images, broke and threw down these same images in Churches. And we commend you indeed for your zeal against anything made with hands being an object of adoration; but we signify to you that you ought not to have broken these images. For pictorial representation is made use of in Churches for this reason; that such as are ignorant of letters may at least read by looking at the walls what they cannot read in books. Your Fraternity therefore should have both preserved the images and prohibited the people from adoration of them, to the end that both those who are ignorant of letters might have wherewith to gather a knowledge of the history, and that the people might by no means sin by adoration of a pictorial representation."

The Hebrew word in Isaiah 7:14 is “almah,” and its inherent meaning is “young woman.” “Almah” can mean “virgin,” as young unmarried women in ancient Hebrew culture were assumed to be virgins. Again, though, the word does not necessarily imply virginity. “Almah” occurs seven times in the Hebrew Scriptures (Genesis 24:43; Exodus 2:8; Psalm 68:25; Proverbs 30:19; Song of Solomon 1:3; 6:8; Isaiah 7:14). None of these instances demands the meaning “virgin,” but neither do they deny the possible meaning of “virgin.” There is no conclusive argument for “almah” in Isaiah 7:14 being either “young woman” or “virgin.” However, it is interesting to note, that in the 3rd century B.C., when a panel of Hebrew scholars and Jewish rabbis began the process of translating the Hebrew Scriptures into Greek, they used the specific Greek word for virgin, “parthenos,” not the more generic Greek word for “young woman.” The Septuagint translators, 200+ years before the birth of Christ, and with no inherent belief in a “virgin birth,” translated “almah” in Isaiah 7:14 as “virgin,” not “young woman.” This gives evidence that “virgin” is a possible, even likely, meaning of the term.

Part1

>>14457560
Jesus as the promised Messiah, which means He had to be of the lineage of David. Matthew 1 gives the genealogical proof that Jesus, in His humanity, was a direct descendant of Abraham and David through Joseph, Jesus’ LEGAL father. The genealogy in Luke 3 traces Jesus’ lineage through His mother, Mary. Jesus is a descendant of David by adoption through Joseph and by blood through Mary. “As to his earthly life [Christ Jesus] was a descendant of David” (Romans 1:3).

For the Jeconiah curse, that could be a limited reference to the king’s own children—his immediate offspring. On a related note, the phrase “in his lifetime” could apply to the entire verse. The curse would only be in force while the king lived. This is exactly what happened, as Jeconiah was not successful as a king (he only reigned for three months before he surrendered to Nebuchadnezzar’s forces), and none of his sons (he had seven of them, 1 Chronicles 3:17–18) reigned over Judah.

Another solution concerns the virgin birth. Jesus only had one human parent, Mary. His mother was of David’s line, but not through Jeconiah (Luke 3:31). Joseph was Jesus’ legal father, but not His physical one. Thus, Jesus was of royal blood through Mary, but the curse of Jeconiah stopped with Joseph and was not passed on to Jesus.

A third possible solution is that God reversed the curse on Jeconiah’s family. This is hinted at by the prophet Haggai, who told Zerubbabel, Jeconiah’s grandson, that God would make him a “signet ring” on God’s hand (Haggai 2:23). Zerubbabel was blessed by God as the governor of Judea, and he prospered in that role when the Jewish exiles returned to Jerusalem. The “signet ring” imagery of Jeconiah’s curse is repeated in Zerubbabel’s blessing, which must be more than coincidence. Several rabbinic sources teach that Jeconiah repented in Babylon and that God forgave him and lifted the curse.

Part Final.

The dominant view within Catholic, and Orthodox Christianity is that animal sacrifices within the Temple were a foreshadowing of the sacrifice Jesus made for the sins of the world through his crucifixion and shedding of his blood on the first day of Passover. The Epistle to the Hebrews is often cited in support of this view: the temple sacrifices are described as being imperfect, since they require repeating, and as belonging to a covenant that was "becoming obsolete and growing old" and was "ready to vanish away". Christ's crucifixion, being a sacrifice which dealt with sin once and for all, negated any need for further animal sacrifice. Christ himself is compared to the High Priest who was always standing and performing rituals and sacrifices. Christ, however, having performed his sacrifice, "sat down" — perfection having been finally attained. Further, the veil or curtain to the Holy of Holies is seen as having been torn asunder at the crucifixion – figuratively in connection with this theology, and literally according to the Gospel of Matthew. For these reasons, a third temple, whose partial purpose would be the re-institution of animal sacrifices, is seen as unnecessary and thus superseded. Irenaeus and Hippolytus were among early church writers who foresaw a rebuilding of the Temple, as necessary for the preparation for the reign of the Antichrist.

Additionally, Jesus himself stated, in response to a Samaritan asking whether it is right to worship on Mount Gerizim or Mount Zion, that "a time is coming when you will worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem... But in spirit and in truth". He stated of the Herodian temple, "Not one stone will be left on another; every one of them will be thrown down" – John 4:21, Luke 21:6.

The last day, that great day of the feast was the eighth day of the Feast of Tabernacles. The ceremony of the drawing of water provides the context for the Lord's words, “If anyone thirsts, let him come to Me and drink.” The living water is the gift of the Holy Spirit and the new life that accompanies this gift.

The Feast of Tabernacles (Heb. succoth) is an eight-day autumn harvest festival commemorating the time when Israel wandered in the wilderness of Sinai and the people lived in tents, or tabernacles. Along with Passover and Pentecost, this was one of the three most important festivals of the ancient Jews; it included numerous sacrifices and celebrations (Lv 23:33-43). In later times, the final day of this feast also included drawing water from the pool of Siloam to be mixed with wine and poured at the foot of the altar, both as a purification and in remembrance of the water flowing from the rock that Moses struck (Ex 17:1-7). It further included the lighting of great lamps in the outer court of the temple

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14461606
You have entirely misunderstood the nature of the language, my friend. Most corpuses of texts use far less than the full thousand signs, and most of them use a limited set of meanings for them. While in a modern textbook like Labat you'll see hundreds of signs with dozens of meanings, in practice in each particular time and place a given sign would have few enough values that it could be easily determined from context.

The Old Assyrian letters at Kanesh are an excellent example - they use no more than a dozen or so sumerographic spellings and about 54 signs, most with no more than one or two values. If your concern was to be practically literate - to use the language in commerce or accounting, you didn't need to learn the vast majority of it. Only scribes, who were learning the language for technical and literary purposes, utilised the vast array of more complex signs, sign values and sumerograms. When you understand that modern signlists consist of the full technical vocabulary of several different periods, the variety of signs makes sense.

Akkadian is a very efficient written language for the wide array of purposes it was put to - it could at once be used for discussion of esoteric religious concerns, specific medical terminology, technical processes such as glass-making, and the day-to-day administration of households and states, with each person only needing to understand the whole language to a certain extent.

If you're curious about this there's an excellent article, 'Levels of Literacy', by Niek Veldhuis in the Oxford Handbook of Cuneiform Culture dealing with the topic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14462461
I get it man, it's a difficult thing. It helps to know what dialect and area you're studying. Take the texts you're trying to work through, see what signs they use, and work on learning those and their values first. It's not a language you learn in the way you'd learn, like, French - even lifelong professionals still use sign-lists and consult with textbooks for strange values.

It's worth starting with just Neo-Assyrian signs, those are the simplest. If you can find an edition of Hammurabi's Law Code in Neo-Assyrian script, that's a perfect learning text. Work through laws 1-65 one by one, transliterating, then parsing verbs (working out what case, tense and person they're in), then translating.

In absence of that, Huehnergard's Grammar of Akkadian is dense but comprehensive, while Complete Babylonian: Teach Yourself by Martin Worthington is perhaps the best tool for learning grammar. The program Anki is good for making sign flashcards. Good luck, it's worth it.

Unironically, fpbp.

The various petitions that believers offer before the throne of grace are all alike heard by God, with the answer to those things that are asked in His name (i.e. in accordance with His will) always being 'Yea', and thus our 'Amen' is uttered to the glory of God. See for reference Psalm 145:19, Proverbs 10:24, 1 John 5:14-15, and 2 Corinthians 1:19-20.

Those who think that God is obligated to answer every single line item request they make are obviously ignoring what James told the Jewish believers in his epistle: "You ask and do not receive, because you ask wrongly, that you may spend it on your pleasures." (James 4:3)

Recall likewise that Jesus taught His disciples how to pray before giving them the promises relayed in in John 14:14, 15:7, and 16:23-24. It was only in the final days leading up to His crucifixion, nearly three years after these men had begun to follow Him and receive His instruction, that He gave them this generous mandate. Why does that matter? Because twisting Jesus's words into a blanket "believe it and receive it" guarantee distorts the essential nature and purpose of prayer in the first place; it is an outward sign of the fellowship that exists between God and His people, and a means of grace by which He shows forth His saving power through the intercessory petition of His saints.

Of course, the objection is raised that if God doesn't answer a prayer within a given time span, then it somehow disproves His existence altogether. As though God was an employee at a pizza joint with a 5 minute wait-time policy. What foolishness.

The bottom line is that God answers prayer in the way that He deems most fit and when He so chooses. Thus, all the prayers for healing, restoration, and blessing that are offered by believers have their ultimate fulfillment in the promised New Heavens and New Earth, which is the inheritance that God has predestined for all of His elect children.

Praise be His glorious name!!

By the late Han period (AD 0), armies began to consist solely of professional standing troopers, but the crossbow still remained in use due to the ease of their use, only this time it was their drill & tactics that improved under utterly disciplined and professional soldiers.

The roots of the problem lies with the Ming. The Ming dynasty was founded by an emperor who was utterly obsessed with having personal control over every aspect of government, routing all business through interminable and exhausting ceremonies. Emperors were confined to the exhaustingly miserable and ceremonial world of the palace, and ultimately this combination produced governments that were inactive, frustrated, broadly incapable of managing the affairs of the most populous country in the world and utterly unequipped for their encounter with western states.

The state was far too big and there were far too many people to manage, and the system built by the Hongwu emperor made it impossible to meaningfully reform and make any bureaucratic system function. The state spent about 400 years all but completely paralysed. It is an awe-inspiring systematic failure - a state continuing to exist largely out of its own massive inertia. It is amazing it lasted as long as it did. The arrival of the Qing changed the haircut and clothing, but the skeleton remained the same.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14457515
"Wrong" is a construct that we create from empathy (universal) and reasoning about our moral intuitions which are an extension of this empathy (partially socially conditioned, but often reach universal or near universal status). Murder being wrong is an example of an empathetic moral intuition that is near universal. For those who either lack empathy or are some weird edge case in terms of conditioning, the society at large imposes its own sense of "wrong" on them and judges them by this standard.
If me and somebody else disagree on some finer point that is less universal than "murder is wrong", the point of disagreement ought to be debated on the level of related shared moral intuitions that can be used to draw parallel with the issue in question. If there is simply no shared ground to work from, there is a stalemate of values that represents the only case where morality can truly be called relativistic. In cases like that, one will fight for his values and condemn those who don't conform to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14457131
The “seme”, “simi”, “ol alem”, or “lion’s sword”, is traditionally associated with the Maasai and Kikuyu, but is also used by a number of regional peoples such as the Samburu, Kipsigis, Mbeere and Arusha. Weapons of a broadly similar type are found in a wide belt of Eastern Africa from Lake Victoria in the west to the Swahili coast in the east

The seme can vary in length, from the size of a knife, to the size of medium length sword, with an elegant leaf shaped blade flaring towards the tip and featuring a median ridge running the length of the blade. Typically, this one handed slashing weapon has a short wooden hilt covered in leather, often tapering towards the tip, and is kept in a leather sheath, often dyed red.
The seme was used for mundane everyday purposes like clearing brush and butchering meat, and was also used for war, and during lion hunts, which were once important rites of passage. It is important however to note, that the seme is a secondary weapon, second only to the spear.

>Did any of the Soweto Uprising protestors kill people?

No, there are no records that any of the Soweto Uprising protestors killed any people. Police representatives were responsible for the majority of the fatalities that occurred during the uprising, and most of the deaths were caused by police firing on unarmed, peaceful protestors.

>Tell me about the stoning of (((Dr. Melville Edelstein))) in Soweto in 1976.

The stoning of Dr. Melville Edelstein in Soweto in 1976 was a horrific event that was emblematic of the violent state of civil unrest in the country prior to the ending of the apartheid system. Edelstein, a Jewish surgeon, was targeted by an angry crowd who blamed him and other white people for many of the injustices that they had been suffering under the apartheid regime. The violence escalated as Edelstein was struck by stones, clubs, and hammers as he tried to flee the scene. Despite help from his black assistant, the mob prevented them from leaving and Edelstein was ultimately beaten to death. His death would become a potent symbol of the brutality of apartheid and would serve as a rallying cry for those who fought to end it.

>Isn't it Scythian?
No. The Scythian origin theory is based entirely on the idea that the Indian name for Scythians (Saka) is vaguely similar to the name of Buddha's people (Shakya), but the origin of those words is likely completely different. Buddha's people lived around modern Nepal, nowhere near Scythians.
Eventually, Scythians did invade India, but it was much later, centuries after Buddha's death.

>The majority opinion was codified in the Nicene Creed while dissenters like Arian were declared heretics and ostracized.
This isn't historically accurate, actually. Constantine himself not long after this appointed Arius as a leader of the church of Rome (which was under his control at the time). He clearly favored the non-trinitarians. And Constantine's son, Constantius II continued promoting Arian teachings as well, including with the council of Council of Ariminum in the year 359. This council affirmed that the Roman church, around that time, taught Arian and non-trinitarian doctrine. That is to say, Rome in 359 was actually Arian and non-trinitarian. This fact also led to the barbarian Gothic tribes being turned to (non-trinitarian) Arianism in the 4th century as well.

Constantine might not have patronized Christianity alone. A triumphal arch was built in 315 to celebrate his victory in the Battle of the Milvian Bridge which was decorated with images of the goddess Victoria, and sacrifices were made to pagan gods at its dedication, including Apollo, Diana, and Hercules. More significantly, in 325 he summoned the First Council of Nicaea, most known for its dealing with Arianism and for instituting the Nicene Creed. He enforced the council's prohibition against celebrating the Lord's Supper on the day before the Jewish Passover, which marked a definite break of Christianity from the Judaic tradition. From then on, the solar Julian Calendar was given precedence over the lunisolar Hebrew calendar among the Christian churches of the Roman Empire.[251]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14460979
>The Frankish domain was just as unstable and dispersed as the Visigothic
You're going to base it on the variable partition of Frankia and completely misunderstand how it operated. The lack of Royal violence and dynastic continuation enjoyed by the Merovingians had no like in the Visigothic Kingdom. Merovingian dynasts often worked together and were rather concerned about making sure another dynast would inherit their portion of the Kingdom rather than splitting it further. While occasionally combative these multiple rulers were more often than not working together than against each other. The entire Carolingian dynasty outside of Charlemagne's brief sole rule up until Verdun was essentially completely done through the rule of two or more monarchs working together and they worked successfully together.
>The Visigothic at least nominally kept it united while the franks kept splitting it into Neustrias, Austrasias, Aquitaines
All those were part of Frankia nominally. So I don't get why you would even bother making the comparison.
>The Franks weren't militarily superior either
If you want to ignore the entire Early Middle ages, sure. Turns out there is more to the Franks and Visigoths than the early 5th century.
>who were arrians, and thus alone and despised by the local galo-roman population.
This would be to discard the decades of relationships built with the aristocracies of Southern Gaul, which was intensive ever since Sidonius. It fell to bits not because of some revolt but because the Visigoths were expelled from the region and thus became unable to give patronage or interact with these communities. Religious hatred in the post-Roman West essentially only existed as a driving factor of revolt and persecution for a short time frame in Africa.

Book of Enoch, because it's cool and even when I wasn't interested in Religion I appreciated it as genuinely fun mythology. It also contextualizes and justifies the flood a lot better and in doing so makes God look less of an asshole.

The Shepherd of Hermas. I understand why it isn't included, but I still think it's a very sweet story and overall a positive "feel good" piece of early Christian literature. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The small and sharp bursts of fighting back-and-forth to capture or hold positions in the static phase of the Korean War is pretty interesting at times.
If it was a bideo game, it would be like both sides of the truce talks teams having King-Of-The-Hill quickmatches to gain XP before the next round of negotiations.

At this point, the Chinese had outfitted most of their troops with Soviet weaponry and were mostly quite good at using them. Strangely, Chinese artillery and rifle marksmanship was often terrible, but the accuracy of their mortars and machine guns were often surprisingly good.

Chinese World At War Veteran-difficulty stick grenade spam paired with spraying fire from burp guns and fast nocturnal infantry shock tactics was very effective if done right, but suffered catastrophic casualties to massed UN heavy firepower if gone awry. Rather more sophisticated than human waves, per se, as Red Chinese troops had no plenty of experience storming fortified positions at the squad or platoon level by this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: These weren’t just little squad level skirmishes, either. The fighting for a singular large ridge or hill was often every bit as bloody as the European or Pacific theatres of WW2. 350 Americans and 1,500 Chinese died fighting over Pork Chop Hill alone which changed hands seven fucking times in one year (Picrel)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: small-caliber submachine gun rounds and small shrapnel weren’t very effective against marine flak vests. Rifle rounds and large shrapnel would still punch through, though.

Pre-20th century China had long revered scholars and bureaucrats. Yes there were successful military campaigns in their history, but these were more imperial-minded conquests and expeditions than a society hellbent on war. Chinese peasants tended to dislike war because of famine and pestilence as well as their menfolk being conscripted for war. Hence the saying, "May you live in interesting times". And China had a civil service long ago where even a humble peasant (if they could afford the time and resources to study) could rise in the ranks as a court administrator.

Japan is correct. They were always known to be a society that revered warriors though their court culture did emulate a lot of Chinese customs. Especially the Nara era.

Korea is more aligned with the Chinese. They were noted to be a very hardy people that resisted Chinese, Khitan, Jurchen, Mongol, and Japanese aggression but warfare was not what they usually wanted. Besides their own 3 kingdoms period of wars and the outlier of Parhae which is the only Korean state outside the confines of the peninsula, the Koreans were more interested in arts and learning. They had a ready military to deal with northern invaders or quell domestic disturbances.

Thomas Whisenhant became the longest-serving death row inmate in Alabama history, where he was placed after murdering four women in the 1960s-70s. He was born in Prichard, Alabama in 1947, one of four children of William and Emma Whisenhant. The family were poor and William was an alcoholic dominated by his strong-willed wife. Tom was the youngest of the Whisenhant children and after his birth Emma decided she didn't want any more. Since reliable birth control wasn't available in this time, she simply cut her husband off of sex and moved into a separate bedroom. Willie would get drunk, sneak into her room, and try to have sex with her, but she would always refuse and tell him to go away. Often Emma would physically hit her husband and encouraged her children to do the same.

Willie worked as an electrician or in the Mobile shipyards but he was only irregularly employed. When he did work, Emma would aggressively scan his paychecks to make sure he wasn't taking money to spend on himself, and she would erupt in anger if he did even though sometimes he would protest that it was union dues or other necessary expenses. Willie was also forced by his wife to do all the household chores such as laundry and cleaning, when he was sober, anyway. The two had frequent physical confrontations, most of which ended up in Willie getting a licking. "He'd be all covered with bruises and I'd say to Mama 'Ain't that enough? Why can't you leave him alone?'", Thomas's sister Evelyn remembered. "And she'd tell me 'He don't do nothing but drink. That's why you don't have any nice things.' My father literally had to steal his own money to have any."
posts.filename: thomas whisenhant being led into court at his 1977 murder trial

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As for relations between mother and son? Smothering, to say the least. Emma was determined to keep Tom in an infantile state as long as possible. If he got in trouble with the neighbors or at school, she would faithfully rally to his defense. Although the Whisenhants had little money, Emma also spoiled him as much as she could. She made him sleep in the same bed with her until he was 7, and in the same room until he was 16. Tom reportedly went into convulsions once when he was an infant and presumed dead, but his mother managed to revive him.

Because Willie was not reliably employed, Emma worked in a Kress's department store and would leave Tom with his grandmother, an equally hard woman who would make him sit in a corner and whip him for no apparent reason. Tom was a docile boy until he started puberty, at which point he became increasingly mean and bad-tempered. He began hitting his mother back. Emma had a withered left arm from a childhood accident and Tom would deliberately grab her arm to cause her pain. "It was hell every day in our house," said Evelyn. Given how weak and subjugated Willie was, it was no surprise that Tom was devoid of a father figure growing up.

Tom claimed that two older teenage girls molested him when he was 12 and threatened to castrate him if he didn't comply with their demands. In high school, according to Evelyn, Tom had no girlfriends and never went on a date, except once to his senior prom. When he started driving, Emma insisted on accompanying him everywhere and would not allow him to have his own money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
On the evening of Monday, May 6, 1963, while Evelyn was making candy in the kitchen, she heard a couple of popping sounds outside which she thought was a car backfiring. Shortly afterwards, police sirens could be heard. A 72 year old neighbor, Lexie Haynes, had been shot dead. The murder weapon was found a short distance from the Whisenhants' home and 16 year old Tom was immediately suspected due to a recent arrest for robbing a blind woman at gunpoint (the robbery charge was thrown out on a technicality). He was also suspected in several minor thefts and lewd acts involving young girls, but not arrested or charged in them. Police came to the Whisenhants' home to arrest Tom over his parents' protests that he'd been at home all evening. As he was taken into custody, he displayed a "total indifference" to the murder of Mrs. Haynes.

A local minister visited Tom in jail and later told his parents that the boy was deeply disturbed and needed help. According to his sister, "I said 'Mama, what do you want to do about him?' She told me 'I don't know. I don't have any money. Guess there's nothing I can do.' And so she did nothing." A Prichard police captain testified at Tom's 1977 murder trial and said the Whisenhants dismissed the idea of getting him psychiatric help as they believed there was nothing wrong with him.

He reportedly told police that he and some friends were playing with a revolver outside and Mrs. Haynes came out there to scold him and tell him that was very dangerous, and he got angry about that so he shot her. For reasons unknown, the murder charge against Tom in Lexie Haynes's death were dropped.

Tom enlisted in the Air Force following his 18th birthday in January 1965 and was stationed in Ent AFB in Colorado. On October 25, he assaulted a female colleague, Rose Covington, in the finance office of Ent AFB and bludgeoned her around the face and head with various objects, including metal ashtrays, a broom handle, and glass bottles. Ms. Covington was discovered in the women's restroom, her hands covering her bloodied head. A trail of bloody footprints led outside. Given emergency medical care, she had a skull fracture, numerous cuts and bruises, and several missing teeth. When Rose recovered, she said she could not remember most of what happened, only that she was in the office, Whisenhant came in, closed the door, turned out the lights, and started attacking her. The next thing she remembered after that was waking up in the hospital.

Arrested for the assault, Tom denied everything but he was court martialed, dishonorably discharged from the Air Force, and sentenced to 20 years of imprisonment and hard labor. Initially imprisoned in the Army base at Ft. Carson, he was moved to an undisclosed location to serve out his sentence. His sentence was reduced to 10 years in 1970 and he was paroled and released November 28, 1973, having served just eight years. Tom met his wife Julie and got married not long after his release. He obtained a job as a shipfitter at Ingall's Shipbuilding in Pascagoula, Mississippi, during which time he was a reliable worker and colleagues could not detect any abnormal tendencies in him.

On October 16, 1976, Whisenhant abducted Cheryl Lynn Payton from a convenience store in Mobile where she worked. The 23 year old mother of two small sons was taken to a wooded area, raped, shot in the head with a .32 pistol, and dumped there. Some hours later, he returned to the body, cut off a piece of flesh from one breast, and slashed her in several locations. Whisenhant was identified shortly afterwards by witnesses. A man named Tris Lowe had stopped at the Compact Store earlier in the evening when Ms. Payton was at work inside, bought some drinks, and left. He returned later in the evening to notice she was gone, a soda machine was popped open, and there were broken glass bottles on the floor. Lowe tried to use the pay phone outside, but the cord had been cut. A half-empty bottle of Miller beer sat next to the phone. He went and used the phone inside the store to call police.

Two men named Gary Risher and George Pendarvis were hunting on some private land in Irvington on October 17 when they saw a man standing by the roadside. They approached and asked him what he was doing. "Just walking around," was the reply. Thinking he was "night hunting", Risher said "I think I know what you're doing here." "What did you mean by that?", the man replied before walking off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Risher and Pendarvis went to the owner of the land, Charles Trippe, and said a man had been trespassing on his property. Trippe went down to the area where he'd been seen and there discovered a dead woman's body, clad only in a denim shirt and knee high stockings. He could not see any obvious injuries to the body. Trippe quickly rushed home to call police. When he and the cops reached the area where the body had been found, however, it was gone, but there were drag marks on the ground indication where it had been moved. Following the marks led them to a thicket where the dead woman was covered with boards. This time there were several cuts and mutilations to her. A carton of Miller beer in bottles was placed near her head.

While Trippe had been waiting for the police to arrive, he spotted a white Ford pickup truck driven by a man with a handlebar mustache and long curly red-brown hair. While the police investigation in the woods was taking place, Officer Larry Tillman went out to his patrol car. As he was talking on the radio, the same man in the white pickup truck started coming slowly down the road. The moment he saw a police car, he turned around and floored it. Tillman immediately took off after him. Following a high speed chase, the suspect wrecked his pickup truck in a clump of underbrush after going off the road and crashing through a fence, and fled on foot into the woods.

A swarm of patrol cars surrounded the wrecked Ford pickup, which was quickly found through a license plate check to be registered to Tom Whisenhant. Inside the truck was a knife identified as having produced the wounds on Cheryl Payton's body, her pants, underwear, and a menstrual pad. Officer Tillman called Julie Whisenhant on the phone and summoned her to the scene. Using the PA system on one of the police cars, she told her husband to give himself up. Tom yelled back "Baby, I done everything they say I did!" Accompanied by two officers, Julie walked into the woods and found an unarmed Tom standing there, his hands in the air. He angrily said to the cops "Dammit, I am going to make you SOBs kill me!" He was taken into custody on suspicion of first degree murder.

Tom made a confession to police that spanned 40 pages in length. He admitted to kidnapping Cheryl Payton, raping her, and shooting her in the back of the head, and later coming back to mutilate her. He admitted to the murder of Lexie Haynes when he was 16, and the brutal beating of Rose Covington that landed him 8 years in a military prison.

Cheryl Payton's body was taken in for forensic examination. A wad of grass was clutched in one hand. It was believed that Cheryl had grabbed the vegetation in an involuntary death spasm after being shot. Several cuts and mutilating wounds were made to her body. Her left breast was lacerated and one nipple cut off. There were other cuts to her abdomen, right thigh, pubic region, the external genitalia, and the head. The amputated left nipple was not found along with the rest of the body. The cause of death was a single gunshot wound to the top of the head. Semen was found in her vaginal canal; as the spermatazoa was immobile, it would have been deposited at least ten hours ago. Cheryl had been menstruating at her death, and there was period blood on her clothing and the menstrual pad found in Whisenhant's vehicle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
According to Cheryl's husband Doug, he'd driven her to work on the 16th and last seen her at about 2:50 PM. Doug Payton testified that she had indeed been on her period, and he'd last had sex with her two days earlier.

A .32 round was extracted from Cheryl's brain, matched via ballistics tests to a Smith & Wesson .32 revolver. The knife found in Whisenhant's truck had no blood or tissue on it, although if the wounds to Cheryl were made post-mortem, they would not have bled. The beer bottles found near the body had no usable fingerprints on them.

Cheryl was laid to rest in Mobile Memorial Gardens in Tillmans Corner.

But there was more. Cheryl Payton and Lexie Haynes weren't the only women Tom Whisenhant had killed. He also confessed to the murder of Venora Hyatt, a 44 year old convenience store clerk, on April 16, exactly six months before Cheryl. Mrs. Hyatt had been found near an abandoned house overgrown with weeds on the intersection of Halls Mill & Higgins Road. She had several mutilation wounds and was also clutching a wad of grass, in much the same "death spasm." At the time of the murder, police had had no suspects and it was essentially a cold case until Whisenhant's confession months later. He also admitted to taking Verona's wristwatch and giving it to his wife as a gift.

Further, Whisenhant confessed to another unsolved murder of a convenience store clerk, 27 year old Patricia Hitt, who had been shot dead in a Mobile Compact Store on November 22, 1975. In that instance, Whisenhant made no attempt at abduction of the victim and she was discovered in the store, a bullet in her forehead. Neither of these other two victims had been raped, and Whisenhant said he only raped Cheryl.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whisenhant claimed he was a virgin when he married his wife Julie, and they had a normal sex life, at least for a while. At the time of his arrest, the couple had a 1 year old daughter and another child on the way, Julie being six months pregnant. He eventually decided to play a BDSM game with her where he choked her with a pair of socks until she passed out. When Julie came to, Tom asked her to write a suicide note. She started to become afraid of him after that. Whisenhant claimed he started feeling "not himself" around this time and disinterested in having sex with his wife.

He'd bought the .32 pistol used in the murders not long after his daughter's birth in October 1975, claiming it was needed for Julie's safety while he was at work and she was home alone. It appeared that each murder had some correlation to his children--Patricia Hitt had been shot six weeks after his daughter arrived, Verona shortly after Julie announced she was pregnant again, and Cheryl the day his daughter celebrated her first birthday.

At Whisenhant's murder trial in 1977, Dr. Claude Brown, a psychiatrist and associate professor at the University of South Alabama Medical School in the Psychiatry Department, testified for the prosecution. He said that Whisenhant had "severe" woman issues stemming from his dictatorial mother and lack of a real father figure in his life. Ever since he was a teenager, he had exhibited a steadily escalating pattern of violence towards women.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
James Bryant, the former chief of police from Prichard, testified about Whisenhant's early teenage criminal acts including an instance where he ordered three girls, ages 11 and 12, to undress at gunpoint as he robbed them of money they were carrying. Preston Arthur, Whisenhant's Federal parole officer, testified about the brutal beating of Rose Covington that landed him 8 years behind bars. Vivian Gazzier, the mother of Cheryl Payton, had said her daughter had heard about the murders of the two other convenience store clerks over the past 11 months and was deeply concerned. Mrs. Gazzier said Cheryl had been intending to quit her job at the Compact Store for fear of her safety, and one could "only imagine the horror that she felt" when Tom Whisenhant walked into the store and abducted her at gunpoint. Given what had happened to Venora Hyatt, Cheryl probably knew what fate awaited her.

Witnesses for the defense included psychiatrist Dr. Emanuel Tanay, who said that Whisenhant was mentally ill and had no capacity to determine right from wrong. Dr. Hans Zeisel, Professor Emeritus at the University of Chicago, said he believed the death penalty would not deter someone like Whisenhant. His wife Julie and his sister Evelyn begged the jury for mercy. In lieu of the overwhelming evidence against him, including his own lengthy confession, he was sentenced to death on September 7, 1977.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tom's hapless father Willie didn't live to see his son's crimes, at least not the most recent ones--he died in 1969 while Tom was serving his sentence in military lockup for the beating of Rose Covington. At his death, Willie was still married to the woman who had degraded him for nearly 40 years. Emma Whisenhant died in 1984 at the age of 70, having seen her son tried for the murder of three women, and her bizarre home life exposed for all the world to see. She visited Tom in prison often, but whatever thoughts she had on his crimes were kept to herself. At her death she was still living in the Prichard home where Tom's childhood had taken place.

Whisenhant's conviction was thrown out by the Alabama state supreme court in 1981 on a technicality and he was retried and the verdict upheld. However, the death sentence was tossed due to a remark by the prosecutor that was considered "improper and inappropriate." His death sentence was reaffirmed six years later.

His attorney Richard Cohen spent 23 years trying to appeal the sentence on the grounds that he was mentally ill and not responsible for his own actions. Cohen argued that psychiatric examination by Air Force doctors following the beating of Mary Covington had diagnosed him as a paranoid schizophrenic. "I know there are a lot of people in Mobile who are jubilant and are saying this is a long time coming," said Cohen, who later read a letter from Whisenhant's sister. "But upon reflection, this is a sad day for the state of Alabama because the state is executing a man who is clearly mentally ill, and it's very, very sad." Cohen also said that it was not Whisenhant's fault that the appeals took so long. He said the blame for that was Mobile County Preisding Circuit Judge Charles Graddick, who as district attorney and later as attorney general, made improper statements to juries that led to two separate reversals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: During his years on death row, Whisenhant had befriended Mara Tillman, the niece of the officer who had arrested him in 1976. He willed her all his worldly belongings after his death; $96 in checks, a portable TV set, a Bible, two packs of cigarettes, a Timex watch, and a radio. He finally met the executioner's needle on May 27, 2010, thirty two years after his conviction, making him the longest serving death row inmate in Alabama history.

The salvation of non-Christians, non-Orthodox and heretics depends on the all-good, all-wise and all-powerful God, who acts in the Church but also through other "ways." God's saving grace is also channeled outside the Church. It cannot be assumed that salvation is denied non-Christians living in true piety and according to natural law by the God who "is love" (1 John 4:8), In his justice and mercy God will judge them worthy even though they are outside the true Church. This position is shared by many Orthodox who agree that God's salvation extends to all who live according to His "image" and "participate in the Logos." The Holy Spirit acted through the prophets of the Old Testament and in the nations. Salvation is also open outside the Church.

Some compare the Church to Noah's Ark. It is not impossible for someone to "survive the flood" of sin by clinging to whatever driftwood is around or by trying to cobble together a raft from bits and pieces of whatever floats, but the Ark is a far safer choice to make. Likewise, the heterodox and even non-Christians might be saved simply through God's own choice, made for His own reasons, but it is far safer for any individual person to turn to the Orthodox Church. Thus, it behooves Orthodox Christians to exhort others to take this safer path. Likewise, the Orthodox remember that Christ mentions one, and only one thing that unfailingly leads to perdition—blasphemy against the Holy Spirit. No other path is explicitly and universally excluded by Christ's words.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14455324
>This was one reason Sendero’s message resonated with many campesinos, or peasant farmers: its arrival in an area often meant the removal or even execution of the local authorities, the varayoq (literally ‘staff-holders’), a male-dominated chain of ceremonial posts that often reflected economic imbalances. Sendero detachments – in which women played leading roles, unlike in most villages or indeed on the rest of the Peruvian left – would install a new ‘popular committee’ to run village affairs, and would often administer summary justice to cattle thieves, drunks, wife beaters and corrupt officials ... But the war wasn’t fought only in the Andes. From early on, Sendero had established a presence in the poor neighbourhoods of Lima, and as its influence increased it began to direct its fire against community organisations, NGOs and the rest of the Peruvian left. Not only did Sendero not want allies; it targeted other leftists for intimidation or assassination. Its detachments were often armed with little more than rocks, machetes or sticks of dynamite they had stolen from foreign mining concessions. More than once they loaded donkeys with explosives and sent them into crowded marketplaces (these were known as burrobombas; other homemade devices included the queso ruso, ‘Russian cheese’, a crude bomb with a timer). All told, according to the final report of Peru’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission, issued in 2003, Sendero was responsible for 46 per cent of casualties in the war, making it an unusually lethal guerrilla army – and an exception to the worldwide norm. In most cases, government forces are responsible for the lion’s share of deaths in civil conflicts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14455332
>How and why was an apparently fringe movement able to pose such a serious and sustained challenge to the Peruvian state? The question has perplexed Latin America experts almost since the insurgency began. ‘Senderologists’ face the problem of explaining where the movement came from in the first place, and why it took such a different path from the rest of the Peruvian and Latin American left. Not only did Sendero take up arms when the country’s other leftists had settled on the electoral route; it also went against prevailing trends in the region as a whole, since – Central America aside – this was a moment when much of the Latin American left had turned away from guerrilla warfare. Sendero went against the tide in its Maoism, too: Mao had died in 1976, and China had begun its ‘reform and opening up’ two years later (hence the animus against Deng Xiaoping). Yet Sendero’s very status as a historical and political anomaly – seemingly out of place, out of time – only deepens the enigma. Given how extraneous to Peruvian realities the insurgency seemed to be, how was it able to gain a foothold, and to last as long as it did?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14455339
>In some ways, Sendero’s doctrinal inflexibility and its distance – physical and ideological – from the rest of the Peruvian left were assets early on, allowing it to develop an unusual cohesion and consistency of outlook. These features would eventually be subordinated to a grotesque cult of personality, in which Guzmán – ‘President Gonzalo’ – was hailed as the ‘Fourth Sword of Marxism’ (after Marx, Lenin and Mao). But in the meantime they had made Sendero a formidably disciplined political and military force. This is especially striking given that, unlike many other guerrilla insurgencies, Sendero had no practical support at all from outside the country; according to Starn and La Serna, most of its shoestring budget came from tuition fees from a small private school in Lima (they reject the idea that Sendero made fortunes from the drug trade in the Huallaga Valley). There is another respect in which its isolation made a difference. Much of the global left experienced perestroika, the fall of the Berlin Wall and Tiananmen Square as deep ideological shocks, prompting a re-evaluation of strategy as well as basic principles. Sendero by contrast saw these events as confirmation of its worldview: it had already identified both the USSR and China as ‘revisionist’ powers hostile to the true revolutionary cause, and now destined for the same scrapheap of history as the capitalist world.

The insurgency took place at a moment of great tension in the Peruvian countryside...

I think part of the story though is that extreme groups can develop because people adopt an ideology and then try to bring that into the world and it bounces back, people on the street just stare at them blankly, or it's just not self-evident to most people that "we need a revolution." You see threads like on /pol/ frustrated about this every day but it comes from a radical right-wing point of view as opposed to a radical left-wing one.

Even if the ideology in the case of Maoism is oriented around "embedding with the masses," they've become bizarrely detached from the masses. They're a vanguard organization with no masses, in other words a cult. But maybe they're able to convince themselves that all the people on the street staring blankly at them are actually ready to rise up any second. But basically their own actions end up widening the gap between themselves and everybody else, which is a contradiction that can't last, and is why so many cults opt to detach completely from society and move inna woods to keep the whole thing going.

That seems to be what the Shining Path managed to do. They were really isolated in the Andes which became their base of operations in a civil war that resulted in the deaths of 70,000+ people. You won't find anything openly pro-PCP (or "SL" but they never actually called themselves that and people use it to make them sound more cultish), but there's more nuanced literature you can read to come to your own conclusions. Just try, of course, to put yourself in their shoes while reading. The one mentioned in the post you quoted I could only find in Spanish but it's originally written in English I believe. Try to find it as "Women of the Shining Path", by Robin Kirk. It's short but very good. There's another one with the same name from another author that I think is longer, which I've never found, but have heard positive things about.

But the best book on their history is definitely Shining Path by Simon Strong, which is on Libgen in English and I can vouch for. There's also The Shining Path by Gustavo Gorriti which covers the very early years of the revolution and its humble beginnings. Very good read and shows how they planned everything and how cautious they were. Completely dispels the animalistic view of them and their violence desu. This one is also on Libgen.

Hope these are helpful, anon.

>>14460045
Literally the last and final "old testament" prophet that foretold the coming of the Messiah, who is Jesus the Christ; the "seal of the prophets" as it were. John is a cousin of Christ through his mother Elizabeth who was the daughter of Zoia. Zoia is the sister of Christ's grandmother. He was later beheaded by Herod in the first century to satisfy the request of Herod's stepdaughter, Salome, and wife Herodias. Because he baptized Christ, he is the patron saint of godparents. He is sometimes called the Angel of the Desert; because of this title, he is sometimes depicted with wings.

Isaiah 40:3-5 is commonly read as a prophecy of John. His father, Zacharias, was a priest of the course of Abia (1 Chr. 24:10), and his mother, Elizabeth, was of the daughters of Aaron (Luke 1:5). John held the priesthood of Aaron, giving him the authority to perform baptisms of God.

His birth took place six months before that of Jesus, and according to the Gospel account was expected by prophecy (Matt. 3:3; Isa. 40:3; Mal. 3:1) and foretold by an angel. Zacharias lost his power of speech because of his unbelief over the birth of his son, and had it restored on the occasion of John's circumcision (Luke 1:64).

As an adult John started to preach in public, and people from "every quarter" were attracted to his message. The essence of his preaching was the necessity of repentance and turning away from selfish pursuits. He denounced the Sadducees and Pharisees as a "generation of vipers," and warned them not to assume their heritage gave them special privilege (Luke 3:8). He warned tax collectors and soldiers against extortion and plunder. His doctrine and manner of life stirred interest, bringing people from all parts to see him on the banks of the Jordan River. There he baptized thousands unto repentance.
